reviewText: Laurel and Hardy always provided a lot of fun.  When I was a kid, we enjoyed seeing grownup people being silly.

HABEAS CORPUS (1928) was technically Laurel & Hardy's first sound film, as Vitaphone audio discs of music and sound effects were added to what was originally a two-reel silent comedy (there was never any spoken dialogue on those discs). The short is presented here in its silent form. This macabre story was directed by Leo McCarey and James Parrott (Charley Chase's brother). In it, the boys are hired by an oddball professor to perform ghoulish work: retrieve a body at night from a creepy graveyard. Most memorable here are several bumbling attempts to climb a cemetery wall and their fright at a drunk wrapped in a sheet. The VHS tape of BIG BUSINESS / THEY GO BOOM features the best ever L&H film ("Big Business") which is also widely considered one of the greatest cinematic comedies. Both shorts are silent. Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 viewer poll rating found at a film resource website. (6.6) Habeas Corpus (silent-1928) - Stan Laurel/Oliver Hardy/Richard Carle/Charley Rogers/Charles A. Bachman
